Woolly Mammoth: I would choose to bring back the Woolly Mammoth because it is one of the most iconic and fascinating extinct animals. It would be incredible to see this massive creature roam the Earth once again and witness its incredible size and strength. Additionally, it would be fascinating to see how it would adapt to the modern world and how it would interact with humans.

Tasmanian Tiger: The Tasmanian Tiger is another fascinating animal that I would love to bring back to life. It was a powerful predator that was native to Australia and Tasmania. Its stripes made it stand out and it was known for its agility and speed. It would be amazing to see this animal in its natural habitat and observe its hunting techniques.

Dodo: The Dodo is a classic example of a species that was wiped out due to human activity. It would be interesting to see how this flightless bird would adapt to life on Earth once again. Would it be able to survive in the modern world? Would it be able to find food and shelter? These are questions that would be answered if we could bring the Dodo back to life.

Platypus: The Platypus is a unique animal that is native to Australia. It is a monotreme, which means it lays eggs instead of giving birth to live young. It is also known for its webbed feet and bill, which it uses to catch fish. It would be fascinating to see this animal in its natural habitat and observe how it hunts for food.

Saber-toothed Tiger: The Saber-toothed Tiger is a powerful predator that was native to North America. It had long, sharp teeth that it used to hunt and kill prey. It would be incredible to see this animal in its natural habitat and observe its hunting techniques. Additionally, it would be fascinating to see how it would interact with humans if it were brought back to life.
